page.title: 08TRANSPORT AT COMMONSIDE
page.content: THE PEOPLE OF COMMONSIDE RELY SOLELY ON THE ROADS AS THEIR MEANS OF TRAVEL THROUGH THE AREA. THE A7 TRUNK ROAD RUNS THROUGH THE BLOCK, WITH TWO MINOR ROADS LEAVING THIS. THE BUS SERVICE FROM EDINBURGH-CARLISLE RUNS SIX TIMES DAILY ON THE A7 TAKING THE COMMONSIDERS TO THE NEAREST TOWN OF HAWICK FOR THEIR BASIC NEEDS. THESE ROADS RUN IN THE SOUTH-EASTERN CORNER OF THE AREA SO LEAVING THE NORTH-WESTERN AREA COMPLETELY ROADLESS. MOST OF THE PEOPLE RELY ON CARS FOR TRANSPORTATION SO THAT THEY CAN GET AROUND AT THEIR CONVENIENCE. SOME OF THE CARS ARE NOW RUN ON DIESEL LIKE THE TRACTORS AND LANDROVERS. A FEW PEOPLE STILL RELY ON HORSES TO TRANSPORT THEM OVER THE FIELDS TO CHECK LIVESTOCK BUT MANY NOW OWN THREE-WHEELED MOTOR BIKES TO TRANSPORT THEM OVER HILLY GROUND.
